editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,363 texts created during Phase 1 of the project have been released into the public domain as of 1 January 2015. Anyone can now take and use these texts for their own purposes, but we respectfully request that due credit and attribution is given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.p: THE PROPHETESS: OR, THE HISTORY OF DIOCLESIAN.
Written by Francis Beaumont and John Fletcher.
WITH ALTERATIONS and ADDITIONS, After the Manner of an OPERA.
Repreſented at the Queen's Theatre, By Their MAJESTIES Servants.
LONDON, Printed for Jacob Tonſon at the Judges Head in Chancerylane near Fleet-ſtreet. 1690.

list.item: Diocles, after Diocleſian, Firſt a Private Soldier, then elected Empero
Maximinian, Nephew to Diocles, and Emperor by hi • Donation.
Aper, Murtherer of Numerianus, the late Emperor.
Niger, An Honeſt Man, and Great Commander.
Camurius, A Captain, and Creature of Aper's.

list.head: The MASQUE.
list.item: Gods of the Rivers, Fauns, Nymphs, Hero's, Heroines, Shepherds, Shepherdeſſes,
the Graces and Pleaſures, with all the Followers of the Gods and Goddeſſes.

div.head: SCENE I.
div.stage: Scene A Pallace.
Enter Delphia and Druſilla.

sp.speaker: Druſ.
sp.l: 'TIS true, that Diocles is courteous,
And of a pleaſant nature, ſweet, and temperate;
His Couſin Maximinian, proud, and bloody.

sp.speaker: Delp.
sp.l: Yes, and miſtruſtful too, my Girl, take heed:
Although he ſeem to love thee, and affect
Like the more Courtier, curious complement;
Yet have a care.

sp.speaker: Druſ.
sp.l: You know all my Affections,
And all my Heart deſires, are ſet on Diocles.
But Aunt, how coldly he requites this courteſie!
How dull, and heavily he looks upon me!
Although I wooe him ſometimes beyond modeſty,
Beyond a Virgins care; how ſtill he ſlights me,
And puts me ſtill off with your Propheſie,
And the performance of your late Prediction,
That when he's Emperour, then he'll Marry me;
Alas, what hope of that?

sp.speaker: Delp.
sp.l: Peace, and be patient;
For tho' he has now no Badge of Honour on him,
No Eye of Favour ſhining:
And tho' my ſure Prediction of his riſing
(Which can no more fail, than the Day, or Night does;
Nay, let him be aſleep, will overtake him,)
Has found ſome rubs, and ſtops; yet hear me Neece,
And hear me with a faith, it ſhall come to him.
I'll tell thee the occaſion.

sp.speaker: Druſ.
sp.l: Do good Aunt,
For yet I am ignorant.

sp.speaker: Delp.
sp.l: Chiding him one Day,
For being too near, and ſparing for a Soldier,
Too griping, and too greedy: he made anſwer,
When I am Caeſar, then I will be liberal.
I, preſently inſpir'd with holy Fire,
And my Prophetick Spirit burning in me.
Gave anſwer from the Gods; and this it was:

l.hi: Imperator eris Romae, cum Aprum grandem interfeceris.

sp.l: Thou ſhalt be Emperor, O Diocles,
When thou haſt kill'd a mighty Boar. From that time
(As giving credit to my words) he has employ'd
Much of his life in Hunting: many Boars,
Hideous, and fierce, with his own Hands he has kill'd;
But yet not lighted on the fatal one,
Should raiſe him to the Empire. Be not ſad Neece,
'Ere long he ſhall. Come, let us entertain him;
For by this time, I gueſs, he comes from Hunting:
And by my Art I find this very inſtant,
Some great Deſign's on foot.

sp.speaker: Druſ.
sp.l: Heaven proſper it. But ſee
The Emperor, and his Siſter coming hither.

sp.speaker: Delp.
sp.l: And Niger buſie in diſcourſe with 'em.
Now Fate is working for us. Let's away. Exeunt.

div.stage: Enter Charinus, Aurelia, Niger.

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.l: You buz into my Head ſtrange Likelihoods,
And fill me full of doubts; but what proofs Niger,
What certainties, that my moſt Noble Brother
Came to his end by murther? tell me that;
Aſſure me by ſome Circumſtance.

sp.speaker: Nig.
sp.l: I will, Sir.
And as I tell you truth, ſo the Gods proſper me:
I have often nam'd this Aper.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.l: True, you have;
And in myſterious Sences I have heard you
Often break out abruptly.

sp.speaker: Nig.
sp.l: Moſt true, Sir.
Fear of your unbelief, and the Times giddineſs,
Made me I durſt not then go farther. If now you pleaſe,
Out of your wonted Goodneſs, to give credit,
I ſhall unfold the Wonder.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: Do it boldly:
You ſhall have both our hearty Loves, and Hearings.

sp.speaker: Nig.
sp.l: This Aper then, this too much honour'd Villain,
(For he deſerves no mention of a good man)
Great Sir, give Ear; this moſt ungrateful, ſpiteful,
Above the memory of Mankind, miſchievous;
With his own bloody Hands.

sp.speaker: Nig.
sp.l: I am in, Sir;
And if I make not good my Story.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: Forward;
I ſee a Truth would break out, be not fearful.

sp.speaker: Nig.
sp.l: I ſay. this Aper, and his damn'd Ambition,
Cut off your Brother's Hopes, his Life, and Fortunes:
The honour'd Numerianus fell by him;
Fell baſely, moſt untimely, and moſt treacherouſly:
For in his Litter, as he bore him company,
Moſt privately and cunningly he kill'd him.
Yet ſtill he fills the faithful Soldiers Ears
With Stories of his Weakneſs, and looſe Life;
That he dare not venture in the open Air,
And ſhew his Warlike Face among the Soldiers;
The tenderneſs and weakneſs of his Eyes,
Being not able to endure the Sun yet.
Slave that he is, he gives out his Infirmity
(Becauſe he would diſpatch his Honour too)
To ariſe from Wantonneſs, and Love of Women.
And thus he juggles ſtill.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: Oh moſt pernicious,
Moſt bloody, and moſt baſe! Alas, dear Brother,
Art thou accus'd, and after Death, thy Memory
Loaden with Shames and Lies? Thoſe pious Tears
Thou daily ſhowerd'ſt upon my Father's Monument,
(When in the Perſian Expedition
He fell, moſt ſtrangely, by a ſtroke of Thunder)
Made thy Diſgrace and Sins? Thoſe Eyes wept out
The fair Examples of a Noble Nature,
Thoſe Holy Drops of Love, turn'd by Depravers
(Malicious poiſon'd Tongues) to thy Abuſes?
We muſt not ſuffer this.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.l: Now I ſee the Cauſe
Why this inhuman, bloody Villain Aper
Will not come near me.

sp.speaker: Nig.
sp.l: No, he dare not, Sir;
He has an Inmate here, that's call'd a Conſcience,
Bids him keep off.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.l: My Brother honour'd him;
Firſt, made him Captain of his Guard, next, his Friend;
Then to my Mother (to aſſure him nearer)
He made him Husband.

sp.speaker: Nig.
sp.l: And withal, Ambitious;
For then he trod ſo high, his falſe Feet itch'd, Sir,
To ſtep into the Throne.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: If you believe, Brother,
Aper a bloody Monſter (as 'tis plain)
Let's leave diſputing, and do ſomething Noble.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.l: Be rul'd, good Siſter; I am as yet too weak
To meet him in the Field; he has under him
The Flow'r of all the Empire, and the Strength,
The Britain and the German Cohorts, pray be patient.
Niger, how ſtands the Soldier to him?

sp.speaker: Nig.
sp.l: In Fear (Sir) more
Than Love or Honour; he has loſt their Affections,
By his moſt covetous and greedy Griping.
Are you deſirous to do ſomething on him,
That all the World may know you lov'd your Brother?
And do it ſafely too, without an Army?

sp.speaker: Nig.
sp.l: Then ſend out a Proſcription,
Send ſuddenly; and to that man that executes it,
(I mean, that brings his Head) a large Reward,
No common Sum: then doubt not, you ſhall ſee,
Even from his own Camp, from thoſe men who follow him,
Follow, and flatter him, we ſhall find one;
Or, if he miſs, a hundred who will venture it.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: For his Reward, it ſhall be ſo, dear Brother;
So far I'll honour him, who kills the Villain;
For ſo far runs my Love to my dear Brother,
Let him be what he will, Mean, Old, or Crooked,
He ſhall have Me; nay, which is more, I'll love him:
I will not be deny'd.

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.l: You ſhall not, Siſter:
But you ſhall find my Love ſhall go along with it.
See a Proſcription drawn, and for his Recompence
My Siſter, and Half-Partner in the Empire:
And I will keep my Word.

sp.speaker: Nig.
sp.p: And tho' it coſt my Life, I'll ſee it publiſh'd.

sp.speaker: Nig.
sp.l: I am gone, Sir.
It ſhall be ſoon diſpatch'd.

div.stage: Scene a Country-houſe at the Side of a Wood, with the Proſpect of a pleaſant Country at a diſtance.
Enter Diocles, Maximinian, and Geta with a Boar on his Back.

sp.speaker: Get.
sp.l: Withal my heart, I am weary on't;
I ſhall turn Jew, if I carry more ſuch Burthens.
Do you think, Maſter, to be Emperor,
With killing Swine? You may be a good Butcher,
Or allied to an honourable Family of Tripe-wives:
Can you be ſuch an Aſs, my Reverend Maſter,
To think theſe Springs of Pork will ſhoot up Caeſars?

sp.speaker: Dio.
sp.l: Come, leave your fooling, Sirrah,
And think of what thou ſhalt be when I am Emperor.

sp.speaker: Get.
sp.l: Would it would come with thinking, then, o' my conſcience,
I ſhould be at the leaſt a Senator.

sp.speaker: Max.
sp.l: A Sowter,
For that's a Place more fitted to thy Nature.
If thou haſt ſuch an Expectation.
Or ſay the Devil could perform this Wonder,
Can ſuch a Raſcal as thou art hope for Honor?
Such a Log-carrying Clown?

sp.speaker: Get.
sp.l: Yes, and bear it too,
And bear it ſwimmingly. I'm not the firſt Aſs, Sir,
Has born Office, and perform'd it reverently.

sp.speaker: Dio.
sp.l: Thou being the Son of a Tyler,
Canſt thou hope to be a Senator?

sp.speaker: Get.
sp.l: Thou being the Son of a Tanner,
Canſt thou hope to be an Emperor?

sp.speaker: Dio.
sp.l: Thou ſaiſt true, Geta, there's a Stop indeed:
But yet the Bold and Vertuous—

sp.speaker: Get.
sp.l: You ſay right, Maſter,
Right as my Leg; for we, the Vertuous,
Tho' we be Kennel-rakers, Filth, and Scoundrels,
We, the Diſcreet, and Bold—Yet, now I remember it,
Tylers have better Title to be Senators,
And ought to ſtep before you thick-skinn'd Tanners;
For we are higher born than you, no baſe ones,
None of your Groundlings, Maſter.

sp.speaker: Dio.
sp.l: I like thee well;
Thou haſt as good a mind as I have, to this Honor.

sp.speaker: Get.
sp.l: As good a mind (Sir) for a ſimple Plaiſterer;
And when I come to execute my Office,
Then you ſhall ſee.

sp.speaker: Get.
sp.l: An Officer in Fury;
An Officer as he ought to be. Do you laugh at it?
Is a Senator in hope worth no more Reverence?
By theſe Hands, I'll clap you by the Heels
The firſt Hour I come into my Office.

sp.speaker: Max.
sp.p: O, my Conſcience, the Fellow believes it.

sp.speaker: Dio.
sp.l: I, do, do, Geta:
For if I once be Emperor—

sp.speaker: Get.
sp.l: Then will I
(For Wiſe men muſt be had to prop the State)
Not bate a ſingle Ace of a ſound Senator.

sp.speaker: Dio.
sp.p: But what ſhall we do the whil'ſt?

sp.speaker: Get.
sp.l: Kill Swine, and ſowſe 'em,
And eat 'em when you have Bread?

sp.speaker: Max.
sp.l: Why didſt thou run away
When the Boar made toward thee? Art thou not Valiant?

sp.speaker: Get.
sp.l: No indeed am I not,
And think it no Diſhonour to confeſs it.
I took a Tree, 'tis true, gave way to the Monſter:
Heark what Diſcretion ſays, Let Fury paſs;

l.hi: From the Tooth of a mad Beaſt, and the Tongue of a Slanderer,

sp.speaker: Dio.
sp.l: He talks already like a Senator.
Go, take it up, and carry it in; 'tis a huge one;
We never kill'd a larger Swine; ſo fierce too,
I never met with yet.

sp.speaker: Max.
sp.l: Take heed, it ſtirs again. Geta runs up a Tree.
How nimbly the Rogue runs up? He climbs like a Squirrel.

sp.speaker: Dio.
sp.p: Come down, ye Dunce? is it not dead?

sp.speaker: Dio.
sp.p: His Throat's cut, and his Bowels out.

sp.speaker: Get.
sp.l: That's all one,
I am ſure his Teeth are in.

sp.speaker: Dio.
sp.l: Come, take him up, I ſay, and ſee him dreſt;
He's fat, and will be luſty Meat; away with him,
And get ſome of him ready for our Dinner.

sp.speaker: Get.
sp.l: Shall he be roaſted whole?
I'll run in the Wheel my ſelf.

sp.speaker: Max.
sp.l: Sirrah, leave prating,
And get ſome Piece of him ready preſently;
We are weary both, and hungry.

sp.speaker: Get.
sp.l: Well, I'll about it.

What an Inundation of Brewis ſhall I ſwim in?
Exit. Geta.

sp.speaker: Dio.
sp.l: Thou art ſtill dull and melancholy, Couſin,
Diſtruſtful of my Hopes.

sp.speaker: Max.
sp.l: Why, can you blame me?
I can't believe a Jugler.

sp.speaker: Dio.
sp.p: Thou know'ſt ſhe is a Propheteſs.

sp.speaker: Max.
sp.l: A ſmall one,
And as ſmall Profit to be hop'd for by her.

sp.speaker: Dio.
sp.l: Thou art the ſtrangeſt man! How does thy Hurt?
The Boar came very near you.

sp.speaker: Dio.
sp.p: It akes, and troubles thee; that makes thee angry.

sp.speaker: Max.
sp.l: Not at the Pain, but at the Practice, Uncle;
The butcherly, baſe Cuſtom of our Lives now.
Had a brave Enemies Sword drawn ſo much from me,
Or Danger met me in the Head of the Army,
To have bluſht thus i' my Blood, had been my Honour:
But to live baſe, like Swine-herds, and believe too;
To be fool'd out with Tales, and Old Wives Dreams,
Dreams when they're drunk, or ſplenatick.

sp.speaker: Max.
sp.l: Miſtake her? Hang her. To be made her Purvey'rs,
To feed her old Chaps, to provide her daily,
To bring her Feaſts, while ſhe ſits grunting at us,
And blowing out her Prophecies at both Ends.

sp.speaker: Max.
sp.p: Heaven knows, I don't believe it.

sp.speaker: Max.
sp.l: So I would have,
Againſt theſe purblind Prophets; for, look you, Sir,
Old Women will lie monſtrouſly, ſo will the Devil;
They would at leaſt ſeem Holy, ſo would he.
He gives 'em leave now and then to uſe their Cunnings,
Which is, to kill a Cow, or blaſt a Harveſt,
Make young Pigs pipe themſelves to Death, choak Poultry,
And chafe a Dairy-maid into a Fever,
With pumping for her Butter.
But when he makes theſe Agents to raiſe Emperors,
When he diſpoſes Fortune as his Servant,
And ties her to Old Wives Tails—

sp.speaker: Dio.
sp.l: You argue learnedly:
Did you not hear the Prophecy?

sp.speaker: Max.
sp.l: Yes, and laugh at it;
And ſo will any man can tell but Twenty,
That is not blind, as you are, blind and ignorant.
Do you think ſhe knows your Fortune?

sp.speaker: Max.
sp.l: Very well, Sir:
You then believe (for methinks 'tis moſt neceſſary)
She knows her own Fate.

sp.speaker: Max.
sp.l: Dare you but be ſo wiſe to let me try it?
For I am doubtful.

sp.speaker: Max.
sp.l: Come nearer to me,
Becauſe her cunning Devil ſhan't prevent me:
Cloſe, cloſe, and hear. If ſhe can turn this Deſtiny,
I'll be of your Faith too.

sp.speaker: Dio.
sp.l: Do it; I fear not:
For if ſhe knows not this, ſure ſhe knows nothing;
I am ſo confident.

sp.speaker: Max.
sp.l: Faith, ſo am I,
That I ſhall make her old Sides hum.

div.stage: Enter Delphia.

sp.speaker: Dio.
sp.p: She comes: Go take your Stand.

sp.speaker: Max.
sp.p: Now ſhew your Holineſs, or you howl for't, Beldame.

sp.speaker: Del.
sp.l: Now my Son Diocles,
Are you not weary of your Game to day?
And are you well?

sp.speaker: Dio.
sp.l: Yes, Mother, well and luſty:
Only you make me hunt for empty Shadows.

sp.speaker: Del.
sp.l: You muſt have patience; Rome was not built in one day.
And he that hopes, muſt give his Hopes their Currents.
You have kill'd a mighty Boar.

sp.speaker: Dio.
sp.l: But I am no Emperor.
Why do you fool me thus, and make me follow
Your flattering Expectation Hour by Hour?
Riſe early, and ſleep late, to feed your Appetites?
Forget my Trade, my Arms? forſake my Honour?
Oppoſe my ſelf to Hazards of all ſorts,
Only to win the barbarous Name of Butcher.

sp.speaker: Dio.
sp.l: But you are cunning, Mother;
And with that Cunning, and the Faith I give you,
You lead me blindly, to no End, no Honour.

sp.speaker: Del.
sp.l: Be provident,
And tempt not the Gods Dooms, ſtop not the Glory
They are ready to fix on ye: you are a Fool then.
Chearful and grateful Takers, the Gods love,
And ſuch as wait their Pleaſures with full Hopes:
The Doubtful and Diſtruſtful, Heaven frowns at.
What I have told by Inſpiration,
I tell you once again, muſt and ſhall find you.

sp.speaker: Del.
sp.l: Not the Boar they point at:
Nor muſt I reveal further, till you clear it.
The Lots of Glorious men are wrapt in Myſteries,
And ſo deliver'd: Common and ſlight Creatures,
That have their Ends as open as their Actions,
Eaſie and open Fortunes follow.

sp.speaker: Max.
sp.l: I ſhall try
How deep your Inſpiration lies hid in you,
And whether your brave Spirit have a Buckler
To keep this Boar-ſpear off; I'll make ye ſmoke elſe.

sp.speaker: Dio.
sp.l: Knowing my Fortune ſo preciſely, Mother,
Methinks you ſhould be ſtudied in your own,
In your own Deſtiny, methinks, moſt perfect.
Can the Stars now,
Or ſecret Inſpirations you boaſt of,
If a hard Fortune hung, and were now ready
To pour it ſelf upon your Life, deliver ye?
Can they now ſay, Take heed?

sp.speaker: Max.
sp.l: I would know that; I fear your Devil will cozen you,
And ſtand as cloſe as you can, I ſhall be with ye.

sp.speaker: Max.
sp.p: Do you ſo? Do you ſo?

sp.speaker: Del.
sp.l: Yes, and laugh at it, Diocles.
Is it not ſtrange, theſe wild and fooliſh men
Should dare t' oppoſe the Pow'r of Deſtiny?
That Power the Gods ſhake at? Look yonder, Son.

sp.speaker: Max.
sp.p: Have you ſpied me? Then have at ye.

sp.speaker: Del.
sp.l: Do, fling boldly;
Spare not, and hit me if thou canſt.

sp.speaker: Max.
sp.l: I cannot: my Arm's dead, I have no feeling.
Or if I could fling, ſo ſtrong is her arm'd Virtue,
She'd catch the flying Dart.

sp.speaker: Del.
sp.l: Poor, doubtful People,
I pitty your weak Faiths.

sp.speaker: Dio.
sp.l: Oh mercy, Mother!
And from this Hour I'll ſerve you as a Deitie.

sp.speaker: Max.
sp.l: Oh let my Prayers prevail too!
Here, like a Tree I dwell elſe; free me Mother,
And greater than great Fortune I'll Adore ye.

sp.speaker: Del.
sp.p: Be free again, and have more pure Thoughts in ye.

sp.speaker: Dio.
sp.l: Now I believe your words moſt conſtantly;
And when I have that Power you promis'd me—

sp.speaker: Del.
sp.l: Remember then your Vow; my Neece, Druſilla.
I mean to Marry her, and then you proſper.

sp.speaker: Dio.
sp.p: I ſhall forget my Life elſe.

div.stage: Enter Niger, Geta, and Soldiers.

sp.speaker: Get.
sp.p: And ſhall he have, as you ſay, that kills Aper?

sp.speaker: Nig.
sp.l: The Proſcription's up, i'th' Market-place, 'tis up,
There you may read it. He ſhall have half the Empire.

sp.speaker: Nig.
sp.p: And th' Emperor's Siſter, the fair Aurelia for his Wife.

sp.speaker: Get.
sp.l: You ſay well Friend: But hark ye,
Who ſhall do this?

sp.speaker: Get.
sp.l: I think ſo.
Yet I could poyſon him in a Cup of Wine,
He loves that mightily. But when I have done this,
May I lie with the Gentlewoman?

sp.speaker: Nig.
sp.p: Lie with her? I, what elſe man?

sp.speaker: Get.
sp.l: Yes, indeed,
I have known a married man that ne'er lay with his Wife;
Thoſe dancing Days were done.

sp.speaker: Nig.
sp.l: Theſe are old Soldiers,
I'll try their Appetites. Save you, brave Soldiers.

sp.speaker: Nig.
sp.l: 'Tis true, there's one ſet up from the Emperor,
Againſt Volutius Aper?

sp.speaker: Del.
sp.p: Now; now have you found the Boar?

sp.speaker: Dio.
sp.p: I have the meaning now, moſt bleſſed Mother —

sp.speaker: Nig.
sp.l: He has ſcorn'd his Maſter;
And bloodily cut off by Treachery,
His Noble Brother.

sp.speaker: Dio.
sp.l: He is living,
But weak, and ſickly, Sir.

sp.speaker: Nig.
sp.l: He is murther'd;
So you ſhall find it mention'd from the Emperor.
And honeſt faithful Soldiers, pray believe it,
For by the Gods you'll find it ſo; he's murther'd,
The manner how, read in the large Proſcription.

sp.speaker: Del.
sp.p: It is moſt true Son. Aper's a Villain, and a Murderer.

sp.speaker: Dio.
sp.l: I thank you Mother,
And dare believe. Hark you Sir, is the recompence
As you related?

sp.speaker: Nig.
sp.l: As firm as Faith, Sir.
Bring him alive, or dead.

sp.speaker: Max.
sp.l: You have taken a fit time.
The General being out of Town: for tho'we love him not,
Yet had he known this firſt, you had paid for't dearly.

sp.speaker: Dio.
sp.l: 'Tis Niger; honeſt Niger: now I know him.
A true ſound man, the buſineſs may be done.
Make no great ſtay, for your own ſafety, here.

sp.speaker: Nig.
sp.p:
I am gone; I thank you.
Exit Nig.

sp.speaker: Dio.
sp.l: I'll to the Market-place, and read the offer,
Now I have found the Boar.

sp.speaker: Del.
sp.p: Find your own Faith: remember what you Vow'd.

sp.speaker: Get.
sp.l: If my Maſter, and I do this, there muſt be two Emperors.
What Honour to this Empire will it be,
To have two ſuch Emperors, as I, and He? Exeunt.

div.head: SCENE I.
div.stage: The Scene continues.
Enter Delphia, and Druſilla.

sp.speaker: Dru.
sp.l: LEave us, and not vouchſafe a parting kiſs
To her, that in his hopes of Greatneſs lives,
And goes along with him in all his Dangers?

sp.speaker: Druſ.
sp.l: Oh you give it too mild a name;
'Twas more than barbarous! and you join'd in it.

sp.speaker: Druſ.
sp.l: Yes, you have blown his Pride to ſuch a vaſtneſs,
He thinks the Empire of the Earth too little.
This makes him quite forget his humble being;
And can I hope that he, who only fed
With the imagin'd Food of future Empire,
Diſdaining thoſe who gave him Means, and Life,
To nouriſh ſuch Deſires; when he's poſſeſt
Of his ambitious Ends (which muſt fall on him,
Or your Predictions falſe) will ever
Deſcend to look on me?

sp.speaker: Del.
sp.l: Were his intents,
Perfidious as the Seas, or Winds, his Heart
Compos'd of Falſhood; yet the benefit,
The greatneſs of the Good he has from you,
(For what I have confer'd, is thine Druſilla)
Muſt make him firm, and thankful. But if all
Remembrance of the Debts he ſtands ingag'd for,
Find a quick Grave in his Ingratitude:
My powerful Art, that guides him to this height,
Shall make him Curſe the Hour he 'ere was rais'd,
Or ſink him to the Center.

sp.speaker: Druſ.
sp.l: I had rather
Your Art could force him to return that Ardour,
To me, I bear to him; or give me Power
To moderate my Paſſions. Yet I know not,
I ſhould repent your Grant, tho' you had ſign'd it,
(So well I think him worthy of my Love)
But to believe that any check to him,
In his vaſt Hopes, could yield content to me,
Were Treaſon to my Love, that knows no pleaſure,
The Object which it dotes on, being miſerable.

sp.speaker: Del.
sp.l: Pretty ſimplicity, I love thee for't,
And will not ſit an idle looker on,
And ſee it wrong'd. Dry thy innocent Eyes,
And caſt off jealous Fears: (yet Promiſes
Are ſlender Comfort,) and but fancy ought
That's poſſible in Nature, or in Art,
That may advance thy Comfort, and be bold
To tell thy Soul, 'tis thine: therefore ſpeak freely.

sp.speaker: Druſ.
sp.l: You give me a new Life. To conceal from you
My Virgin Fondneſs, were to hide my Sickneſs
From my Phyſician. Oh dear Aunt, I languiſh
For want of Diocle's ſight; he is the Sun
That keeps my Blood in a perpetual Spring;
But in his abſence, cold benumming Winter
Seizes on all my Faculties. Would you bind me,
(Who am your Slave already) in more Fetters?
Oh bear me then (but 'tis impoſſible
I fear to be effected) where I may
See how my Diocles breaks thro' his Dangers,
And in what heaps his Honours fly upon him;
That I may meet him in the Height, and Pride
Of all his Glories; and there
Challenge him as my own.

sp.speaker: Del.
sp.l: Enjoy thy Wiſhes.
This is an eaſie Boon, which at thy Years
I could have given to any.
It ſhall be done, as fits my Skill, and Glory.
From Ceres, I will force her winged Dragons,
And in the Air, hung over the Tribunal;
(The Muſick of the Spheres attending on us)
There, as his good Star thou ſhalt ſhine upon him,
If he prove true; and as his Angel, guard him:
But if he dare be falſe, I in a moment
Will put that Glorious Light out, with ſuch horror,
As if eternal Night had ſeiz'd the Sun,
And all things were returnd to the firſt Chaos,
Or raiſe ſome Monſter to devour him quick.

sp.speaker: Dru.
sp.l: I fear th' Event; but I will do
Whatever you command.

sp.speaker: Del.
sp.l: Reſt then aſſur'd,
I am the Miſtris of my Art, and fear not. Exeunt.

div.stage: Scene a Foreſt.
Enter Aper, Camurius, and Guard, with a Cloſe Litter, richly adorn'd with Figures of Gold, Trophies, and Plumes of White Feathers.

sp.speaker: Aper.
sp.l: Your Care of your ſick Emperor, Fellow-Soldiers,
In Colours to the Life, does ſhew your Love,
And zealous Duty: O continue it.
And tho' I know you long to ſee and hear him,
Impute it not to Pride, or Melancholy,
That keeps you from your Wiſhes; ſuch State-Vices
(Too too familiar with Great Princes) are
Strangers to all the Actions of the Life
Of good Numerianus. Let your Patience
Be the Phyſician to his wounded Eyes,
(Wounded with pious Sorrow for his Father)
Which Time and your long Patience will recover,
Provided it prove conſtant.

sp.speaker: 1 Gua.
sp.l: If he counterfeit,
I will hereafter truſt a prodigal Heir,
When he weeps at his Father's Funeral.

sp.speaker: 2 Gua.
sp.l: Or a young Widow, following a Bed-rid Husband
(After a three-years Sickneſs) to the Fire.

sp.speaker: 1 Gua.
sp.l: Note his Humility, with what ſoft Murmurs
He does inquire his Pleaſures.

sp.speaker: 2 Gua.
sp.p: And how ſoon he is inſtructed.

sp.speaker: Aper.
sp.l: All your Commands (Dread Caeſar) I'll impart
To your moſt ready Soldier, to obey 'em;
So take your Reſt in Peace. It is the Pleaſure
Of mighty Caeſar, (his Thanks ſtill remembred
For your long Patience, with a Donative
Fitting his State to give, ſhall quickly follow)
That you continue a ſtrict Guard upon
His ſacred Perſon, and admit no Stranger,
Of any other Legion, to come near him;
For none but you he'll truſt. I receive
Your Anſwer in your Silence. Now, Camurius,
Speak without Flattery; has not Aper acted
This Paſſion to the Life?

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: I would applaud him,
Were he ſaluted Caeſar: But I fear,
Theſe long-protracted Counſels will undo us:
And 'tis beyond my Reaſon, he being dead,
You ſhould conceal your ſelf, or hope it can
Continue undiſcover'd.

sp.speaker: Aper.
sp.l: That I have killd him,
Yet feed theſe ignorant Fools with Hopes he lives,
Has a great end in't: The Pannonian Cohorts
(That are my own, and ſure) are not come up;
The German Legions waver, and Charinus
(Brother to this dead Dog) (Hells Plagues on Niger,)
Is jealous of the Murther, and I hear,
Is marching up againſt me, 'tis not ſafe,
Till I have Power to juſtifie the Act,
To ſhew my ſelf the Author. Be careful, therefore,
For a ſmall time, (till I have fully ſounded
How the Tribunes and Centurions ſtand affected)
That none come near the Litter. If I find them
Firm to my Party, I'll dare diſcloſe my ſelf;
And then, live Aper's Equal.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: Does not the Body begin to putrifie?

sp.speaker: Aper.
sp.l: That exacts my Haſte.
When but even now I feign'd Obedience to it,
As I had ſome great Buſineſs to impart,
The Scent had almoſt choak'd me. Be careful therefore
All keep at diſtance.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: I am taught my Part,
Haſte you to perfect yours. Exit Aper.

sp.speaker: 1 Gua.
sp.l: I had rather meet
An Enemy in the Field, than ſtand thus nodding,
Like a Rug-gown'd Watchman.

div.stage: Enter Diocles, Maximinian, and Geta.

sp.speaker: Max.
sp.p: A Watch at Noon! This is a new Device.

sp.speaker: Dio.
sp.p: I am arm'd againſt all Danger.

sp.speaker: Max.
sp.l: If I do not ſecond you,
A Coward's Name purſue me.

sp.speaker: Dio.
sp.p: Now my Fate guide and direct me.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: You are rude, and ſaucy,
With your forbidden Feet to touch this Ground,
Sacred to Caeſar only, and to theſe
That do attend his Perſon. Speak, what are you?

sp.speaker: Dio.
sp.l: What thou, nor any of thy Faction are,
Nor ever were; Soldiers, and honeſt Men.

sp.speaker: Dio.
sp.l: No Inſtruments of Craft, Engines of Murther,
That ſerve the Emperor only with oyl'd Tongues,
Sooth and applaud his Vices; and when y'ave wrought
So far upon his Weakneſs, that he's grown
Odious to all the Subject, and himſelf,
You rid him out of the way.

sp.speaker: Dio.
sp.p: 'Tis Truth, and I will make it good.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: Lay hands upon 'em, or kill 'em inſtantly.

sp.speaker: Get.
sp.p: I'll keep my Diſtance; I do not like the Sport.

sp.speaker: Dio.
sp.l: What's he that is
Owner of any Vertue worth a Roman,
Or does retain the Memory of the Oath
He made to Caeſar, that dares lift his Sword
Againſt that Man who (careleſs of his Life)
Comes to diſcover ſuch a horrid Treaſon,
As when you hear't, and underſtand how long
Y'ave been abus'd, will make you mad with Fury.
I am no Stranger, but, like you, a Soldier,
Train'd up one from my Youth; and I ſee ſome
With whom I have ſerv'd; and (not to praiſe my ſelf)
Muſt needs confeſs, they have ſeen Diocles,
In the late Britain Wars, both dare and do
Beyond a Common Man.

sp.speaker: 2 Gua.
sp.p: I know him; the braveſt Soldier of the Empire.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: Stand; if thou advance an Inch, thou art dead.

sp.speaker: Dio.
sp.l: Die thou, Kills Cam.
That durſt oppoſe thy ſelf againſt a Truth,
That will break out, tho' Mountains cover it.

sp.speaker: Get.
sp.l: I fear this is a Sucking Pig, no Boar,
He falls ſo eaſie.

sp.speaker: Dio.
sp.l: Hear me, Soldiers;
And if I make it not apparent to you
This is an Act of Juſtice, and no Murther,
Cut me in pieces: I'll diſperſe the Cloud
That has ſo long obſcur'd a bloody Act,
Ne'er equal'd yet. You all know with what Favours
The good Numerianus ever grac't
The Provoſt Aper.

sp.speaker: Dio.
sp.l: And that thoſe Bounties
Should have contain'd him (if he e're had learn'd
The Elements of Honeſty and Truth)
In Loyal Duty: But Ambition never
Looks backward on Deſert, but with blind haſte
Boldly runs on. But I loſe time. You are here
Commanded by this Aper to attend
The Emperor's Perſon: No, my Friends, you are cozen'd,
The good Numerianus now is paſt
The ſenſe of Wrong or Injury.

sp.speaker: Dio.
sp.p: Let your own Eyes inform you.

div.stage: Opens the Litter, and ſhews the Body of the murther'd Emperor.

sp.speaker: Get.
sp.l: Is this an Emperor's Cabinet?
Fough! I have known a Charnel-houſe ſmell ſweeter.
If Emperors Fleſh have this ſavour, what will mine do,
When I am rotten?

sp.speaker: 2 Gua.
sp.p: And with all Cruelty to be reveng'd.

sp.speaker: 1 Gua.
sp.l: Who is the Murtherer? Name him, that we may
Both puniſh it in him, and all his Family.

sp.speaker: Dio.
sp.l: Who but Aper?
That barbarous, and moſt ungrateful Aper,
His deſperate Poniard printed on his Breaſt
This deadly wound.
Nay, weep not, let your Loves ſpeak in your anger;
And to confirm you gave no ſuffrage to
This damned Plot, lend me your helping Hands
To puniſh the Paricide: And if you find
That there is worth in Diocles to deſerve it,
Make him your Leader.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: A Diocles! A Diocles! A Diocles.

sp.speaker: Dio.
sp.l: We'll force him from his Guards. Now my Stars,
If you have any good for me in ſtore
Shew it, when I have ſlain this fatal Boar. Exeunt.

div.stage: Delphia, and Druſilla, appear in the Air, in a Chariot drawn by Dragons.

sp.speaker: Del.
sp.l: Fix here, and reſt a while your Sail-ſtretch'd Wings,
That have out-ſtript the Winds. The Eye of Heaven
Durſt not behold our ſpeed, but hid it ſelf
Behind the groſſeſt Clouds; and the pale Moon
Pluckt in her Silver Horns; trembling for fear
That my ſtrong Spells ſhould force her from her Sphere.
Such is the power of Art.

sp.speaker: Del.
sp.l: Look down Druſilla. Yonder lofty Towers,
And ſpacious Streets, where every private Houſe
Appears a Pallace to receive a King:
The Site, the Wealth, and Beauty of the Place.
Will ſoon inform thee 'tis Imperial Rome:
Rome, the great Miſtriſs of the conquer'd World.

sp.speaker: Dru.
sp.l: But without Diocles, it is to me,
Like any Wilderneſs we have paſs'd o're.
Shall I not ſee him?

sp.speaker: Del.
sp.l: Yes, and in full glory;
And glut thy eager Eyes with looking on
His proſperous ſucceſs. Contain thy ſelf:
For tho' all things beneath us are tranſparent,
The ſharpeſt ſighted, were he Eagle-Ey'd,
Cannot diſcover us. Nor will we hang
Idle Spectators to behold his Triumph.
sp.stage: Enter Diocles, Maximinian, Senators, Guard, with Aper Priſoner, Geta, and Officers.
sp.l: But when occaſion ſhall preſent it ſelf,
Do ſomething to add to it. See, he comes.

sp.speaker: Druſ.
sp.l: How God-like he appears! with ſuch a grace
(The Giants, that attempted to ſcale Heaven
When they lay dead on the Phlegrean Plain)
Mars did appear to Jove.

sp.speaker: Dio.
sp.l: Look on this,
And when with horror thou haſt view'd thy deed,
(Thy moſt accurſed deed) be thy own Judge,
And tell me if thou canſt perſwade thy ſelf,
To Hope, or Plead for Mercy?

sp.speaker: Ape.
sp.p: No; I confeſs, my Life's a burthen to me.

sp.speaker: Dio.
sp.l: Thou art like thy name, a cruel Boar.
I long have hunted for thee; and ſince now
Thou art in the Toil, it is in vain to hope,
Thou ever ſhalt break out.
Yet ſince my future Fate depends upon thee,
Thus to fulfil great Delphia's Propheſie,

Aper (thou fatal Boar) receive the honour
kills Aper.
To fall by Diocles Hand. Shine clear my Stars,
That met when I had entrance to the World,
And give Applauſe to this great Work.

sp.speaker: Druſ.
sp.p: Oh now you honour me! A Symphony of Muſick in the Air.

sp.speaker: Max.
sp.l: This ſhews the Gods approve the Perſon, and the Act.
But hark

lg.l: GReat Diocles the Boar has kill'd,
Which did infeſt the Land;
What Heart is not with Rapture fill'd?
Who can his Joys command?
Down, down the bloody Villain falls,
Hated, contemn'd of All;
And now the mighty Spirit calls,
For Rites of Funeral.

lg.head: CHORUS.
lg.l: Sing Io's! praiſe the Thundring Jove,
Pallas and Venus ſhare;
Since the All-charming Queen of Love,
Inſpires the God of War.
CHaron, the peaceful Shade invites,
He haſtes to Waft him o're;
Give him all neceſſary Rites,
To land him on the Shore.
Sound all your Inſtruments of War,
Fifes, Trumpets, Timbrels play;
Let all Mankind the Pleaſure ſhare,
And bleſs this happy Day.

lg.head: CHORUS.
lg.l: Sound all your Inſtruments, &c.

sp.speaker: Max.
sp.l: Now if the Senate
(For in the Soldiers Eyes I read their Love)
Think Diocles worthy to ſupply the place,
Of dead Numerianus; as he ſtands
His Heir in his revenge; with one conſent
Salute him Emperor.

sp.speaker: 1 Sen.
sp.l: Long live Diocles,
Auguſtus, Pater Patriae, and all Titles
That are peculiar only to the Caeſar's,
We gladly throw on him.

sp.speaker: 1 Gua.
sp.l: We confirm it,
And will defend his honour with our Swords,
Againſt the World; raiſe him to the Tribunal.

sp.speaker: 1 Sen.
sp.l: Fetch the Imperial Robes: And as a ſign
We give him abſolute power of Life, and Death,
Bind this Sword to his Side.

sp.speaker: 2 Sen.
sp.p: Omit no Ceremony, that may be for his honour.

div.stage: While they Inveſt him with the Imperial Robes, this Martial Song is ſung: Trumpets and Ho-Boys joining with them.

lg.l: LET the Soldiers rejoyce,
With a general Voice,
And the Senate new Honours decree 'em;
Who at his Armies Head,
Struck the fell Monſter dead,
And ſo boldly, and bravely did free 'em.

lg.head: CHORUS.
lg.l: Rejoyce, Rejoyce, &c.
To Mars let 'em raiſe,
And their Emperors praiſe,
A Trophy of the Armies own making;
To Maximinian too,
Some honours are due,
Who joyn'd in the brave undertaking.

lg.head: CHORUS.
lg.l: Rejoyce, Rejoyce, &c.
With Flowers let 'em ſtrow,
The way as they go,
Their Statues with Garlands adorning,
Who from Tyrannies Night
Drave the Miſts in their Sight,
And gave 'em a glorious Morning.

lg.head: CHORUS.
lg.l: Rejoyce, Rejoyce, &c.

div.head: Then a Symphony of Flutes in the Air, and after this SONG.

lg.l: SInce the Toils and the Hazards of War's at an end,
The Pleaſures of Love ſhould ſucceed 'em;
The Fair ſhould preſent what the Senators ſend,
And compleat what they have decreed 'em.
With Dances and Songs, with Tambours and Flutes,
Let the Maids ſhew their Joy as they meet him;
With Cymbals and Harps, with Viols and Lutes,
Let the Husbands and True Lovers greet him.

lg.head: CHORUS.
lg.l: Let the Prieſts with Proceſſions the Hero attend,
And Statues erect to his Glory;
Let the Smoak from the Altars to Heaven aſcend,
All ſing Great Diocles Story.

sp.speaker: Max.
sp.l: Still the Gods
Expreſs that they are pleas'd with the Election.

sp.speaker: Get.
sp.l: My Maſter is an Emperor, and I feel
A Senators Itch upon me. Would I could hire
Theſe fine inviſible Fidlers to play to me
At my Inſtalment.

sp.speaker: Dio.
sp.l: I embrace your Loves,
And hope the Honours which you heap on me
Shall be with Strength ſupported. I deſire no Titles,
But as I ſhall deſerve 'em. I will keep
My Name, but with this difference, I will add
To Diocles but two ſhort Syllables,
And be call'd Diocleſianus.

sp.speaker: Get.
sp.l: This is fine.
I'll follow the Faſhion, and when I am a Senator,
I'll be no more plain Geta, but be call'd
Lord Getianus.

sp.speaker: Dru.
sp.p: He ne'er thinks of me, nor of your Favour.

div.stage: Enter Niger.

sp.speaker: Del.
sp.l: If he dares prove falſe,
Theſe Glories ſhall be to him as a Dream,
Or an Inchanted Banquet.

sp.speaker: Nig.
sp.l: From Charinus,
From Great Charinus, who with joy has heard
Of your Proceedings, and confirms your Honours.
He, with his beauteous Siſter, fair Aurelia,
Are come in Perſon, like themſelves attended,
To gratulate your Fortune.

sp.speaker: Dio.
sp.l: For thy News,
Be thou in France Pro-Conſul. Let us meet
The Emperor with all Reſpect and Honour.

div.stage: Trumpets. Enter Charinus, Aurelia, Attendants.

sp.speaker: Dru.
sp.l: Oh Aunt! I ſee this Princeſs does eclipſe
The luſtre of my Beauty, tho' I were
My ſelf to be the Judge.

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.l: 'Tis Vertue, and not Birth, that makes us Noble.
Great Actions ſpeak Great Minds, and ſuch ſhould govern;
And you are grac'd with both. Thus, as a Brother,
A Fellow, and Copartner in the Empire,
I do embrace you: May we live ſo far
From Difference, or emulous Competition,
That all the World may ſay, although two Bodies,
We have one Mind.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: When I behold this Object,
The dead Numerianus, I ſhould waſh
His Wounds with Tears, and pay a Siſter's Sorrow
To his ſad Fate: but ſince he lives again
In your moſt brave Revenge, I bow to you,
As to a Power which gave him ſecond Life,
And will make good my Promiſe. If you find
That there is Worth in me that may deſerve you,
Altho' my Youth and Fortune may require
Both to be ſu'd and ſought to, here I yield
My ſelf to be your Wife.

sp.speaker: Dio.
sp.l: Oh you Gods!
Teach me how to be thankful; you have pour'd
All Bleſſings on me, that ambitious Man
Could ever fancy. Till this happy minute
I ne'er ſaw Beauty, or believ'd there could be
Perfection in a Woman. On my Knees
I thus receive you; and, if you vouchſafe it,
This day I am doubly married, to the Empire,
And your fair ſelf.

sp.speaker: Del.
sp.l: Falſe and perfidious Villain—

sp.speaker: Dru.
sp.l: Let me fall headlong on him. Oh my Stars!
This I foreſaw, and fear'd.

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.l: Call in a Flamen; this Knot
Shall inſtantly be ty'd.

sp.speaker: Del.
sp.l: But it ſhall not,
If Art or Hell have any ſtrength.

div.stage: Enter a Flamen. Thunder and Lightning. The Stage ts darkned on a ſudden. A dreadful Monſter comes from the further end of the Scenes, and moves ſlowly forward.

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.l: The Signs are fatal.
Juno ſmiles not upon this Match, and ſhews
She has her Thunder too. Defer the Marriage,
Or this fell Monſter will devour you all.

sp.speaker: Dio.
sp.p: Can there be a Stop to all my Happineſs?

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.l: We were too violent,
And I repent my haſte. Firſt let us pay
All Rites of Funeral to my dead Brother;
Perhaps that may appeaſe the angry Gods.

div.stage: The Muſick flouriſh. They who made the Monſter ſeparate in an inſtant, and fall into a Figure, ready to begin a Dance of Furies.

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.l: 'Tis wonderful. Here, take up the Body;
And when we have plac'd his Aſhes in his Urn,
We'll try the Gods again.

div.stage: Exeunt Trumpets and Drums, ſounding and beating a dead March.

sp.speaker: Del.
sp.l: So, 'tis deferr'd yet, in deſpite of Falſhood.
Comfort, Druſilla; for he ſhall be thine.
Some Rites I muſt perform to Hecate,
To perfect my Deſigns; Which finiſh'd once,
He ſhall be made obedient to thy Call,
Or in his Ruine I will bury all.

div.head: SCENE I.
div.stage: Scene a Room, Chairs in it, the Hangings and Figures Grotesk.
Enter Maximinian.

sp.speaker: Max.
sp.l: WHat powerful Star ſhin'd at this Man's Nativity,
And bleſt his homely Cradle with full Glory?
What Throngs of People preſs and buz about him,
And with their humming Flatteries ſing him Caeſar?
How the fierce-minded Soldier bows before him?
Charinus ſues, the Emperor intreats him;
And his bright charming Siſter doats on him:
All worſhip him; yet I'm ſtill Maximinian:
What have I got by this? I have gone as far
To wooe this purblind Honour, as he has;
And done as much, run thro' as many Perils:
Only the Executioner of Aper,
(Which I miſtook) has made him Emperor,
And me his Slave.

div.stage: Enter Delphia and Druſilla.

sp.speaker: Del.
sp.l: Stand ſtill, he cannot ſee us, till I pleaſe.
This Diſcontentment I have forc'd into him,
For thy Cauſe, my Druſilla.

sp.speaker: Max.
sp.l: Can the Gods ſee this?
See it with Juſtice, and confer their Bleſſings
On him, that never flung one Grain of Incenſe
Upon their Altars, never bow'd his Knee yet?
And I, that have march'd Foot by Foot, ſtruck equally,
Contemning his baſe, covetous—

sp.speaker: Max.
sp.l: Bleſs me, ye Gods! And with all Reverence— Kneels.

sp.speaker: Del.
sp.l: Stand up, my Son;
And wonder not at thy ungrateful Uncle:
I know thy Thoughts, and I appear to eaſe 'em.

sp.speaker: Max.
sp.l: Oh Mother! did I ſtand the tenth part to you
Engag'd and fetter'd, as my Uncle does,
How would I ſerve, how would I fall before you?
How worſhip and adore you?

sp.speaker: Del.
sp.l: Peace, and flatter not;
Neceſſity and Anger draws this from you,
Of both which I forgive you. For your Uncle,
'Twas I foretold this Honour, it fell on him,
Fell to his full Content. He has forgot me,
For all my Care, forgot me, and his Vow too;
And I have forgot him; let him ſtand faſt now.
Come hither: My Care ſhall be for you.

sp.speaker: Max.
sp.p: Oh bleſſed Mother! She charms him. Maximinian,

sp.speaker: Del.
sp.l: Stand ſtill, and let me work. So now,
Go and appear in Court, and eye Aurelia;
Stand in her Vew, make your Addreſſes to her;
Prepare ſome Muſick, and then ſhew your ſelf,
And mark the Conſequence: I'll ſay no more,
But Fortune is your Servant; go, and be happy.

sp.speaker: Max.
sp.p: I know all this is holy Truth.

sp.speaker: Dru.
sp.l: Yet all this cures not me:
You had full as much Belief from Diocleſian.

div.stage: Enter Geta, Lictors, and Suitors with Petitions.

sp.speaker: Del.
sp.l: Be not dejected, I have warn'd you often;
The proudeſt Thoughts he has, I'll humble. Who's this?
O, 'tis the Fool, and Knave, grown a grave Officer:
He's hot with high Preferment.

sp.speaker: Get.
sp.l: What's your Bill? For Gravel for the Appian Way,
And Pills. Is the Way Rheumatick?

sp.speaker: Get.
sp.l: Remove me thoſe Piles to Port Eſqueline,
'Tis fitter for the Place. You ſhall be paid.

sp.speaker: Get.
sp.l: Thank me when you have it;
Thank me another way, you you are an Aſs elſe.
I know my Office. Lord, how theſe Fellows throng!
That Knave has eaten Garlick; whip him, and bring him back.

sp.speaker: 2 Suit.
sp.l: I beſeech your Worſhip;
Here's an old Reck'ning for the Dung and Dirt, Sir.

sp.speaker: Get.
sp.l: It ſtinks like thee; away. Yet let him tarry.
Let's ſee your Bill: Give your Petitions
In ſeemly ſort, and keep your Caps off decently.
For ſcowring the Water-courſes thro' the City?
A fine Periphraſis for a Kennel-raker.
Did you ſcowr all, my Friend? You had ſome Buſineſs.
Who ſhall ſcowr you? You're to be paid, I take it,
When Surgeons ſwear you have perform'd your Office.

sp.speaker: Get.
sp.l: We muſt be ſometimes witty,
To nick a Knave; 'tis uſeful to our Gravity.
I'll take no more Petitions; I am peſter'd;
Give me ſome Reſt?

sp.speaker: 3 Suit.
sp.l: I have brought the Gold (an't pleaſe ye)
About the Place you promis'd.

sp.speaker: Get.
sp.p: See him enter'd. How does your Daughter?

sp.speaker: Get.
sp.l: This is too little: But let me ſee your Daughter;
'Tis a good forward Girl. I'll take no more Petitions.

sp.speaker: Get.
sp.l: Look to your Places, or I'll make you ſmoak elſe.
I drank a Cup of Wine at your Houſe yeſterday,
It was ſmart Wine, my Friend.

sp.speaker: Lic.
sp.p: Send him the Piece; he likes it.

sp.speaker: Get.
sp.p: And eat the beſt Wild Boar at that ſame Farmer's.

sp.speaker: 2 Suit.
sp.l: I have half left yet; your Worſhip ſhall command it

sp.speaker: Get.
sp.l: A Bit will ſerve. Give me ſome reſt. Gods help me
How ſhall I labour when I am a Senator?

sp.speaker: Del.
sp.l: 'Tis a fit Place indeed. Save you, Sir.
Does not your Worſhip know us?

sp.speaker: Get.
sp.l: Theſe Women are ſo troubleſom.
There be Houſes providing for ſuch wretched Creatures,
Houſes of ſmall Rents, to ſet old Wives a ſpinning.

sp.speaker: Dru.
sp.l: We are no Spinſters, Sir, nor, if you look on us,
So wretched as you take us.

sp.speaker: Del.
sp.l: Does your Mightineſs
(For that's a great Deſtroyer of the Memory)
Yet underſtand our Faces?

sp.speaker: Get.
sp.l: Prethee keep off, Woman.
It is not fit I ſhould know every Creature.
What tho' I was familiar heretofore?
I muſt not know thee now: my Place neglects thee;
Yet 'cauſe I have a glimps of your remembrance,
Give me your Sutes, and wait me a Month hence.

sp.speaker: Del.
sp.l: Our Suites (Sir) are, to ſee the Emperor,
The Emperor Diocleſian, to ſpeak with him;
And not to wait on you. We have told you all Sir.

sp.speaker: Get.
sp.l: I laugh at your ſimplicity, poor Women.
To ſee the Emperor; you are deceiv'd now;
The Emperor appears but once in ſeven Years,
And then he ſhines not on ſuch Weeds as you are.
Yet now I think on't; wait in that Room of State,
Perhaps he may come forth. All leave me but my Officers.

sp.speaker: Del.
sp.l:
I thank you, Sir;
Ex. Suit.

Come my Druſilla, we ſhall ſee him there.
Ex. Del. Druſ.

sp.speaker: Get.
sp.l: I am too merciful, I find it Friends;
Of too ſoft a nature for an Officer;
I bear too much remorſe.

sp.speaker: Lic.
sp.l: 'Tis your own fault, Sir:
For look ye, one ſo newly warm in Office,
Should lay about him blindfold, like true Juſtice;
Hit where it will: the more you Whip and Hang Sir,
(Tho' without cauſe, let that ſhew it ſelf afterward)
The more you are admir'd, and fear'd, Sir.

sp.speaker: Get.
sp.p: I think it ſhould be ſo.

sp.speaker: Lic.
sp.l: Your Country-men are by nature Cholerick,
And prone to Anger.

sp.speaker: Get.
sp.l: Nay, I can be Angry;
And the beſt is, I need ſhew no reaſon for't.

sp.speaker: Lic,
sp.l: You need not, Sir, your Place is without reaſon;
And what you want in Learning, and in Judgment,
Make up with Rule, and Rigor.

sp.speaker: Get.
sp.l: A rare Counſellor!
Inſtruct me further. Is it fit, my Friend,
The Emperor, my Maſter Diocleſian,
Should now remember, or the Times, or Manners,
Call'd him, plain, down-right Diocles?

sp.speaker: Lic.
sp.p: He muſt not; it ſtands not with his Royalty.

sp.speaker: Get.
sp.l: I grant ye.
I being then the Edile Geſtianus,
A Man of Place, and Judge; is it held requiſite
I ſhould commit to my conſideration,
Thoſe Raſcals of remov'd, and ragged Fortunes,
Who with unreverend Mouths, call'd me Slave Geta?

sp.speaker: Lic.
sp.p: You muſt forget their Names; your Honour bids you.

sp.speaker: Get.
sp.l: I will forget 'em, but I'll hang their Natures.
I will aſcend my Place, which is of Juſtice;
And Mercy I forget thee.

sp.speaker: Lic.
sp.p: A rare Magiſtrate! another Solon ſure.

sp.speaker: Get.
sp.l: An Hour hence I'll ſit in State, in this Place,
And then, hang all are brought before me. Exeunt.

div.stage: A Curtain falls repreſenting the entrance into the inner part of a Magnificent Pallace. A noble Arch; behind it two Embroider'd Curtains, part of the firſt ty'd up on either ſide, the farther Curtain hanging down. Figures of Diana, on each ſide of the Arch ſtanding on large Pedeſtalls.
Enter Diocles.

sp.speaker: Dio.
sp.l: How am I croſs't, and tortur'd?
My moſt wiſht Happineſs, my lovely Miſtriſs,
Who muſt compleat my Hopes, and link my Greatneſs,
Yet ſevered from my Arms? Tell me, high Heaven,
How have I ſinned, that you ſhould ſpeak in Thunder?
In horrid Thunder, when my Heart was ready
To leap into her Breaſt, the Prieſt was ready,
The fair Aurelia ready. You gave the honour,
And ere you gave it full, could you deſtroy it?
Or was there ſome dire Star? ſome Devil that did it?
Some ſad malignant Angel to my honour?
With you, I dare not rage.

sp.speaker: Del.
sp.l: With me thou canſt not,
Tho' it was I; nay look not pale, and frighted;
I'll fright you more: with me thou canſt not quarrel.
I rais'd the Thunder to rebuke thy falſhood.
Look here, to her thy falſhood. Now be angry,
And be as great in Evil, as in Empire.

sp.speaker: Del.
sp.l: True, thou haſt need of Bleſſing.
'Twas I that at thy great Inauguration,
Hung in the Air unſeen. 'Twas I that honour'd thee
With various Muſick, and ſweet ſounding Airs.
But why did I all this? To keep thy Honeſty,
Thy Vow, and Faith; that once forgot, and ſlighted,
All other Bleſſings leave you; nay Aurelia
(Unleſs thou ſoon repent) ſhall ſcorn, and hate thee.

sp.speaker: Druſ.
sp.l: Yet conſider,
As you are Noble, as I have deſerv'd ye;
For yet you are free. If neither Faith, nor Promiſe,
Nor Deeds of former times may be remembred;
Let theſe new dropping Tears, for I ſtill love you,
Theſe Hands held up to Heaven. —

sp.speaker: Dio.
sp.l: I can pitty you, but that is all; I'll not diſſemble with you,
I muſt not offer more, 'twere moſt unwiſe in me.

sp.speaker: Dio.
sp.l: Nor honorable,
A Princeſs is my Love, ſhe dotes on me;
A fair, and lovely Princeſs is my Miſtriſs.
I am an Emperor: conſider Propheteſs,
I am now for Queens, for none but Divine Beauties;
To look ſo low as this cheap common ſweetneſs,
Would ſpeak me mean ſtill, and my Glories nothing.
I grant I made a Vow; what was I then?
As ſhe is now, of no note, (Hope made me Promiſe,)
But as I am, to keep this Vow were monſtrous,
A madneſs, and a low inglorious fondneſs.

sp.speaker: Druſ.
sp.l: Princes may love with Titles,
But I with Truth.

sp.speaker: Del.
sp.l: Take heed: here ſtands thy Deſtiny.
Thy Fate depends on her.

sp.speaker: Dio.
sp.l: Thou doating Sorcereſs;
Would'ſt have me love this thing? that is not worthy
To wait upon my Saint, to be her Shadow.
A Princeſs is her ſlave; when ſhe appears
Bows her beck. The mighty Perſia's Daughter
(Bright as the breaking Eaſt, as mid-day Glorious)
Waits her commands, is proud to ſerve her Pleaſures.
Some honorable Match I will provide for her,
That ſhall advance you both; mean time I'll ſmile on you.

div.stage: Exit.

sp.speaker: Del.
sp.l: Mean time I'll haunt you. Cry not Child, be confident.
'Ere long thou ſhalt more pitty him, (obſerve me)
And pitty him in truth, than now thou ſeekſt him.
My Art ſhall fail me elſe; come, no more weeping. Exeunt.

div.stage: Scene the former Chamber, hung with Grotesk-Work.
Enter Geta, and Lictors.

sp.speaker: Get.
sp.l: Set me my Chair.
And now I'll put on a Face of Authority.
A Whipping, Torturing, Hanging Face; 'tis well.
Now, bring in the Offenders.

sp.speaker: 1 Lic.
sp.p: There are none yet, Sir, but no doubt there will be.

sp.speaker: Get.
sp.l: How? am I ready? and my Anger too?
The fury of a Magiſtrate upon me,
And no Offenders to execute my Rage on?
Ha! no Offenders Knaves?

sp.speaker: 1 Lic.
sp.l: There are Knaves indeed, Sir;
We hope ſhortly to have 'em for your Worſhip.

sp.speaker: Get.
sp.l: No Man to Hang, or Whip? are you good Officers,
To provide no Fuel for a Judges Fury?
In this Place, ſomething muſt be done. This Chair
When I ſit down, muſt ſavour of ſeverity:
Therefore I warn ye all, bring me leud People,
Or likely to be leud; Twigs muſt be cropt too.
Let me have Evil Perſons in abundance,
Or make 'em Evil, 'tis all one; do but ſay ſo,
That I may have fit matter for a Magiſtrate,
Then let me work. If I ſit idle once more,
And loſe my longing; as I am true Edile,
And as I hope to rectifie my Country,
You are the Scabs I'll ſcratch from the Common-Wealth;
You are thoſe Raſcals of the State I'll puniſh,
And you ſhall find, and feel it.

sp.speaker: 1 Lic.
sp.p: You ſhall have many, many notorious People.

sp.speaker: Get.
sp.l: Let 'em be People,
And keep notorious to your ſelves. Mark me Lictors,
If I be angry; as my Place will ask it:
And want fit matter to execute my Authority on:
I'll hang a hundred of you. I'll not ſtay
To inquire further into your Offences.
It is ſufficient that I find no Criminals,
And therefore I muſt make ſome; let that ſuffice.
For ſo runs my Commiſſion.

div.stage: Enter Delphia, and Druſilla.

sp.speaker: Del.
sp.l: You muſt not mourn ſtill; ſome recreation
To allay this ſadneſs, muſt be ſought. What's here?
Some ſenceleſs People Worſhipping a Sign in Office.

sp.speaker: Get.
sp.l: Lay hold on her, and hold her faſt;
She'll ſlip thro' your Fingers like an Eel elſe;
I know her Tricks. Hold her, I ſay, and bind her.
Or hang her firſt, and then I'll tell you wherefore.

sp.speaker: Get.
sp.l: Thou haſt done enough to undo thee.
Thou haſt preſs'd to the Emperor's preſence without my Warrant,
I being his Key, and Image.

sp.speaker: Del.
sp.l: You are, indeed, an Image;
And of the courſeſt Stuff, and the worſt making,
That 'ere I lookt on yet.
I'll make as good an Image of an Aſs.

sp.speaker: Get.
sp.p: Beſides, thou art a Woman of a leud life.

sp.speaker: Del.
sp.l: I am no Whore, Sir, nor no common fame
Has 'ere proclaim'd me vitious to the People.

sp.speaker: Get.
sp.l: Thou art to me, a damnable leud Woman,
Which is as ſtrong a proof as if Forty ſwore it.
I know thou art a keeper of tame Devils,
And whereas great and grave Men of my Place,
Can by the Law be allow'd but one a piece
For their own Services and Recreation,
Thou, like a Traiterous Quean, keep'ſt twenty Devils,
Twenty in Ordinary.

sp.speaker: Del.
sp.l: Pray, Sir, be pacified,
If that be all; and if you want a Servant,
You ſhall have one of mine ſhall ſerve for nothing;
A faithful, diligent, and a wiſe Devil.
For what uſe do you want one?

sp.speaker: Get.
sp.l: Let her go.
We men of buſineſs muſt uſe ſpeedy Servants.
Let me ſee all your Family.

sp.speaker: Del.
sp.p: You ſhall; I have Devils of all kinds ready for you.

sp.speaker: Get.
sp.l: Let me ſee; a Devil for Intelligence? No, no,
He will lye beyond all Travellers. A State Devil?
Neither; he'll out-do me at my own Weapon.
An Evidencing Devil? he'll out-ſwear me,
And turn my Plots upon my ſelf. An impudent Devil?
That can out-face a Judge upon the Bench.
He may hang others, then he may hang me.
A holy Devil? one that can out-do
The High-Prieſt in Hipocriſie. That's dangerous:
He'll broach ſome new Religion; and we are
Already over-ſtockt with ſeeming Saints;
Or over-zealous mad men, that are as bad.
A Devil that can ſpeak all Languages:
To entertain Embaſſadors in their own Tongues,
Or elſe ſome pleaſant Airie, Dancing Devils,
To treat the Ladies with, who viſit me.
Thoſe would do well.

sp.speaker: Del.
sp.l: It ſhall be done.
Sit there; and if you love your own Life, ſtir not.
'Ill give you a taſte of my Art immediately.
You ſee thoſe Antick Figures in the Hangings.

sp.speaker: Del.
sp.l: They are all Spirits; all at my command.
My Servants all, and they ſhall entertain you;
Come forth, and Dance before this mighty Edile.
Come forth, and leave your Shaddows in your places.

stage.hi: The Figures come out of the Hangings and Dance: And Figures exactly the ſame appear in their places: When they have danc'd a while, they go to ſit on the Chairs, they ſlip from 'em, and after joyn in the Dance with 'em.

sp.speaker: Get.
sp.p: Shall theſe Devils be at my command?

sp.speaker: Del.
sp.l: They ſhall be more obedient than your ſlaves.
You ſhall have other Spirits if you pleaſe,
Shall take you up, and bear you thro' the Air;
Hurricania, appear; and take him up.

sp.speaker: Get.
sp.p: O deliver me! deliver me! Get. runs off, the Lictors follow him.

sp.speaker: Del.
sp.l: So; I have frighted him ſufficiently,
He'll trouble us no more. Come my Druſilla,
Th' Embaſſadors of Perſia are now
With th' Emperor Charinus and Aurelia,
Demanding freedom for their Maſter's Siſter,
The fair Caſſana, whom the haughty Princeſs
Shall ſtill retain, and ſend th'Embaſſadors
In diſcontent away. Come, do not grieve,
Thou ſoon ſhalt ſee this proud ingrateful man,
So miſerable, thou ſhalt pitty him. Exeunt.

div.stage: Scene a Magnificent Pallace.
Enter Charinus, Aurelia, Caſſana, Ambaſſadors, and Attendants.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: Never diſpute with me, you ſhall not have her;
Nor name the greatneſs of your King, I deſpiſe him.
Your Knees move nothing; ſhould your Maſter bow thus,
It were his Duty, and my Power ſhould ſcorn him.

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.l: She is her Woman (never ſue to me)
And in her Power to render her, or keep her.
She is my Siſter, not to be compell'd,
Nor have her own ſnatcht from her.

sp.speaker: Amb.
sp.l: We only beg her,
To name what Ranſom ſhe will pleaſe to think of,
Jewels, or Towns, or Provinces.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: No Ranſom,
No not your Kings own Head, his Crown upon it,
And all the low ſubmiſſions of his People.

sp.speaker: Amb.
sp.p: Fair Princeſs's, ought to have tender thoughts.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: Is ſhee too good,
To wait upon the mighty Emperor's Siſter?
What Princeſs of that Sweetneſs, or that Excellence?
Sprung from the proudeſt, and the mightieſt Monarchs,
But may be highly bleſt, to be my Servant?

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: Has my fair uſage
Made you ſo much deſpiſe me, and my Fortune,
That you grow weary of my Entertainments?
Henceforward, as you are I will command you;
And as you were ordain'd my Priſoner,
My Slave, and one I may diſpoſe of any way,
No more my fair Companion: tell your King ſo.
I'll uſe her as I pleaſe, and that's your Anſwer.

sp.speaker: Amb.
sp.l: Our Maſter with a mighty Army's near;
I know he'll venture all to free his Siſter; Aſide.
You are the cauſe then of the War: for ſince

Entreaty can't prevail, force muſt compel.
Ex. Amb.

div.head: Muſick and a SONG.
div.stage: Enter Maximinian, he ſtands gazing on the Princeſs all the time of the Song.

lg.l: WHat ſhall I do to ſhow how much I love her?
How many Millions of Sigh's can ſuffice?
That which wins other Hearts, never can move her,
Thoſe common methods of Love ſhe'll deſpiſe.
I will love more than Man 'ere lov'd before me,
Gaze on her all the Day, melt all the Night;
Till for her own ſake at laſt ſhe'll implore me,
To love her leſs to preſerve our delight.
Since Gods themſelves could not ever be loving,
Men muſt have breathing Recruits for new Joys:
I wiſh my Love could be always improving,
Tho' eager Love more than Sorrow deſtroys.
In Fair Aurelia's Arms leave me expiring,
To be Embalm'd by the Sweets of her Breath;
To the laſt Moment I'll ſtill be deſiring:
Never had Hero ſo glorious a Death.

sp.speaker: Max.
sp.l: Now, if thou be'ſt a Propheteſs, and canſt do
Things of that wonder that thy Tongue delivers,
Canſt raiſe me too, now ſhew thy mighty Pow'r.
How ſhe eyes me?
How ſweet, how fair, and lovely ſhe appears?
Her Eyes, like bright Noon-beams, ſhoot thorow me.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: Oh my dear Friend, where have you been?

sp.speaker: Max.
sp.l: Where am I?
Who does ſhe take me for? Work ſtill, work ſtrongly.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: Why have you fled my Love, and my Embraces?

sp.speaker: Max.
sp.p: Is this real? I dare not truſt my Senſes.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: Can a Clap of Thunder,
The Cauſe being as common as the Noiſe is,
Strike Terror to a Soldier's Heart? a Monarch's?
Thro' all the Fires of angry Heaven, thro' Tempeſts,
That ſing of nothing but Deſtruction,
Even underneath the Bolt of Jove, then ready,
And aiming dreadfully, I would ſeek you,
And fly into your Arms.

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.l: Fie, Siſter, fie:
What a forgetful Weakneſs is this in you?
What a light Carriage? Theſe are Words and Offers
Due only to your Husband Diocleſian.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: 'Tis ſtrange,
That only empty Names compel Affections.
This Man you ſee, give what Name or Title,
Let it be ne'er ſo mean, ne'er ſo deſpis'd; Brother,
This lovely Man—

sp.speaker: Max.
sp.p: Tho' I be hang'd, I'll on.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: This Man, I ſay,
Let him be what he will, or bear what Fortune,
This moſt unequal'd Man, deſerves the Bed of Juno.

sp.speaker: Max.
sp.l: I hope ſhe is; I am ſure I am little better.
My Uncle comes. Now if ſhe's firm, I am happy.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: What Man is this? Away; What ſawcy Fellow?
How came this baſe mean Creature to my Preſence?

sp.speaker: Dio.
sp.l: Have you forgot me, Fair? Or do you jeſt with me?
I'll tell you how I came; pray look more kindly.
Nothing but Frowns and Scorns!

sp.speaker: Dio.
sp.p: I'll tell you who: I am your Husband, Madam.

sp.speaker: Dio.
sp.p: Yes, to you, Madam: I am Diocleſian.

sp.speaker: Max.
sp.l: More of this ſport, and I am made. Oh Mother!
Compleat what is begun.

sp.speaker: Dio.
sp.l: I am he, Madam,
Reveng'd your Brother's Death, ſlew cruel Aper.
I am he the Soldier courts, the Emperor honours,
Your Brother loves. I am he (my beauteous Miſtris)
Will make you Empreſs of the World.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: 'Tis falſe, thou art not he: Thou that brave Man!

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.p: Is there no Shame, no Modeſty in Woman?

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: Thou one of his high Rank!

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: Generous, and Noble! Fie, thou art no ſuch Perſon
Thou art a poor Dalmatian Slave, a low thing,
Not worth the Name of Roman. Stand off, further.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: Come hither, my Endymion;
Come ſhew thy ſelf, and bleſs all Eyes look on you.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: Thou fair Star that I live by,
Look lovely on me, break into full Brightneſs.
Here is a Face now of another making,
Another Mould; here's a Divine Proportion;
Eyes fit for Phoebus ſelf to gild the World with.
Look there, and wonder. Now behold that Fellow,
That admirable Face, cut with an Ax out.

sp.speaker: Dio.
sp.p: And do you ſpeak this truly?

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.p: She's mad, and you muſt pardon her.

sp.speaker: Dio.
sp.p: By Heaven, ſhe hangs on him!

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.p: Be not diſturb'd, Sir; 'tis but the Fondneſs of her Fit.

sp.speaker: Dio.
sp.p: I am fool'd; and if I ſuffer this—

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.l: Pray be pacifi'd; this Fit will ſoon be off.
Let her go, Sir; a little Reſt will bring her to her ſelf.

sp.speaker: Dio.
sp.p: Baſe as thou art, how durſt you touch that Lady?

sp.speaker: Max.
sp.l: I am your Kinſman, Sir; no ſuch baſe Fellow:
I ſought her not, nor had I any reaſon
To thruſt a Princeſs from me; 'twas no Manners.
What ſhe beſtow'd was Courteſie, and I thank her.

sp.speaker: Max.
sp.l: I will, and I will go with Glory off,

And magnifie my Fate.
Exit Maximinian.

sp.speaker: Dio.
sp.p: Good Sir, leave me; I am a Trouble to my ſelf now.

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.l: I am ſorry for't, and hope
You'll find it but a Womans Fit to try you.

sp.speaker: Dio.
sp.l: It may be ſo.

Into what miſery has Fortune brought me,
Exit Charinus.
And how long muſt I ſuffer? Poor humble Beings,
Tho' they know Want and Hunger, know not theſe,
Know not theſe killing Fates: A little ſerves 'em,
And with that little they're content. O Honour!
How greedily Men ſeek thee! and once purchas'd,
How many Enemies to Man's Peace bring'ſt thou?
When I preſum'd I was bleſt with this fair Woman,

sp.speaker: Del.
sp.p: Behold him now, and tell me how thou lik'ſt him.

sp.speaker: Dio.
sp.l: When all my Hopes were up, and Fortune ſhew'd me
To all the World, the Greateſt, Happieſt Monarch;
Then to be cozen'd, to be cheated baſely,
By my own Kinſman too! I'll kill the Villain.
But can I kill her Hate too? No, he wooes not;
She ſeeks him. Shall I kill an Innocent?
Oh Fortune!
Could'ſt thou find none to fool, and blow like Bladders,
But Kings, and their Contents?

sp.speaker: Dru.
sp.l: Upon my Life, I pity his misfortune.
See how he weeps! I cannot hold my Tears now.

sp.speaker: Del.
sp.l: Away, Fool;
He muſt weep bloody Tears before thou haſt him.
How fare you now, brave Diocleſian?
For ſhame! tyr'd with your Love? Has too much Pleaſure
Dull'd your mighty Faculties?

sp.speaker: Dio.
sp.l: Art thou there,
More to torment me? Doſt thou come to mock me?

sp.speaker: Del.
sp.l: I do, I come to laugh at all thy Sufferings;
I who have wrought 'em, come to ſcorn thy Sorrows.
I told thee once, this is thy Fate, this Woman;
And as thou uſeſt her, ſo thou ſhalt proſper.
It is not in thy power to turn this Deſtiny,
Nor ſtop the Torrent of thy Miſeries.
Thou who didſt think no Power could croſs thy Pleaſure,
Shalt find a Fate above thee.

sp.speaker: Dru.
sp.p: Good Aunt, ſpeak mildly; behold how pitiful he looks.

sp.speaker: Dio.
sp.p: I find, and feel too, that I am miſerable.

sp.speaker: Dio.
sp.p: And didſt thou work this Miſchief?

sp.speaker: Del.
sp.p: I did, and will purſue it.

sp.speaker: Dio.
sp.l: O ſtay, and have ſome pity: Fair Druſilla,
Thou that haſt lov'd me, let me beg of thee,
I know my Suit muſt ſeem unjuſt to thee,
To make thy Love the means to loſe it ſelf:
Yet, Oh! have pity on me.

sp.speaker: Del.
sp.l: Peace, Child; this Softneſs may become thy Love,
But not my Anger: The ſame Kindneſs he ſhews thee,
The ſame Aurelia ſhall ſhew him, no farther;
Nor ſhall the Wealth of all his Empire change this.

sp.speaker: Dio.
sp.l: I muſt ſpeak fair. Lovely young Maid, forgive me;
Look gently on my Sorows; you can grieve too,
I ſee it in your Eyes; and thus I thank you. Kneels.

sp.speaker: Dru.
sp.p: Oh Aunt! now I am bleſt!

sp.speaker: Dio.
sp.p: Be not both young and cruel. Kneeling I beg it ſtill.

sp.speaker: Dru.
sp.p: Riſe, Sir, I grant it. Now, Aunt, he is my own.

div.stage: Enter Aurelia.

sp.speaker: Del.
sp.p: Thou art deceiv'd; not yet, Girl.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: Oh my dear Lord! how have I wrong'd your Patience?
How wandred from the Truth of my Affections?
How like a wanton Fool, ſhunn'd that I lov'd moſt?
But you are full of Goodneſs to forgive, Sir,
As I of Grief to beg, and Shame to take it.
Sure I was not my ſelf; ſome Dream wrought on me,
Or ſtrange Illuſion: Can you pardon it?

sp.speaker: Dio.
sp.l: All my Delight!
My Life! I with more pleaſure take thee,
Than if there had been no ſuch Dream; for certain,
It was no more.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: Now you have forgiven me,
I'll take my leave. The good Gods bleſs ſuch Goodneſs. Ex. Au.

sp.speaker: Del.
sp.l: You ſee how Kindneſs proſpers. Be ſo juſt
To marry my Druſilla; ſee then what Joys,
What Pleaſures, greater than this Lady can beſtow,
Shall always wait on you.

sp.speaker: Dio.
sp.l: I'll die a Dog firſt.
Now I am reconcil'd, I will enjoy her,
In ſpite of all thy Spirits, and thy Witchcrafts.

sp.speaker: Dio.
sp.l: I will, old doating Devil.
Look thou appear no more to croſs my Pleaſures:
And wert thou any thing but Air and Spirit,

My Sword ſhould end the Difference.
Exit Diocles.

sp.speaker: Del.
sp.l: I contemn thy Threats. Come, look up, Girl:
The Perſians ſhall lay an Ambuſh for 'em,
And they ſhall fall into the Net, they ſhall.
If he repent not ſoon, I have a Spell
Shall make him feel on Earth the Plagues of Hell. Exeunt.

div.trailer: The End of the Third Act.

div.head: SCENE I.
div.stage: Scene the Great Curtain.
Enter Delphia and Druſilla.

sp.speaker: Del.
sp.l: TIs done, Druſilla, the great Work is done;
Are all the Perſian Monarch's Priſoners;
He has 'em in his Power. Now ſmile, Druſilla.

sp.speaker: Dru.
sp.p: Where was my Diocles when this was done?

sp.speaker: Del.
sp.l: Why he was with 'em; but his Pow'r was vain,
As vain all the Reſiſtance he could make;
They bore their Priſoners off, and he was left—

sp.speaker: Dru.
sp.l: How, left! Oh do not torture me with Doubt,
But tell me he is ſafe, and tell me quickly,
Or I ſhall die with Fear.

sp.speaker: Del.
sp.l: He is (my Girl) in his own Army, ſafe;
Thou ſhalt behold him inſtantly.

sp.speaker: Dru.
sp.l: Lie ſtill, my trembling Heart, ſince he is well.
But how was this effected?

sp.speaker: Del.
sp.l: I made the Perſians lay an Ambuſh for 'em,
Then drew 'em from the Camp to take the Air,
Attended with a ſtrong and choſen Guard.
I made 'em wander at a Diſtance from 'em,
And brought 'em where the Perſians lay conceal'd,
And put 'em in their power. Then Diocleſian,
Calling aloud for Succour to the Guard,
Soon gave 'em the Alarm, and made 'em fly
With all the Wings of Speed, to reſcue 'em;
Which they had quickly done, had I not rais'd
A Miſt, which hid the Perſians from their Sight,
Guiding 'em till they bore their Priſoners off.
Here comes the Emperor, ready to burſt
With Anger and Deſpair, for this Diſgrace:
We'll ſtand aſide, and mark him.
When Niger, and the reſt of 'em are gone,
We'll ſhew our ſelves.

div.stage: Enter Diocleſian, Niger, Senators, Guard, and Soldiers.

sp.speaker: Dio.
sp.l: Talk not of Comfort; I have broke my Faith,
And the Gods fight againſt me.
Could it elſe have been
In Nature, that a few weak Perſians
Could (almoſt in my Armies ſight) have forc'd,
And bore in Triumph off, all that I lov'd,
My Brother and Copartner in the Empire,
The Perſian Priſoner, and my lovely Miſtris?
(A Jewel which I priz'd above my Life.)
Could this have been, and I want pow'r to reſcue 'em,
If the Immortal Gods I have provok'd,
Had not given Spirit to the Undertakers,
And in their bold Deſign protected 'em?

sp.speaker: Nig.
sp.l: Great Caeſar,
Your Safety does confirm you are their Care;
And that howe're their Practices reach others,
You ſtand above their Malice.

sp.speaker: 1 Gu.
sp.l: Do but lead us on,
With that invincible and undaunted Courage
Which waited bravely on you, when you appear'd
The Son of Conqueſt; you ſhall ſee us force
(Tho' all the Enemies of the Eaſt conſpire
Againſt your Undertakings) the proud Perſian
Out of his ſtrongeſt Hold.

sp.speaker: Dio.
sp.l: You give me, Fellow-Soldiers, a new Life;
And tho' (for ſome great Sin) I am markt out
The Object of Heaven's Hate; tho' Jove ſtood ready
To dart his threefold Thunder on my Head,
It could not fright me from a fierce Purſuit
Of my Revenge. I will redeem my Friends,
And with my Friends, my Honour, at leaſt fall,
Fall like my ſelf, a Soldier, and a Roman.

sp.speaker: Nig.
sp.p: Now we hear great Diocleſian ſpeak.

sp.speaker: Dio.
sp.l: Draw up your Legions.
And let it be your care (my much lov'd Niger)
To haſten their remove. And fellow Soldiers,
Your love to me, will teach you to indure,
As much as I ſhall, and I ask no more.

sp.speaker: 1 Gua.
sp.l: Die he accurſt,
Who thinks of reſt, or ſleep, before he has
The Perſians in his view.

sp.speaker: Nig.
sp.l: We know the Honour,
The Dignity of Rome, and what's above
All can be urg'd; the quiet of your Mind,
Depends upon our haſte.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Happineſs, and glorious Victory attend great Caeſar.

div.stage: Exeunt all but Diocleſian.

sp.speaker: Dio.
sp.l: The chearfulneſs of my Soldiers, gives aſſurance
Of good ſucceſs abroad, if firſt I make
My Peace at home here; there is ſomething chides me,
And ſharply tells me, that my breach of Faith,
To Delphia, and Druſilla, is the ground
Of my misfortunes; ſhe was my better Angel,
And thus I do invoke her. All-knowing Delphia!
Thou more, much more than Woman,
Look on thy Creature.
And as thou twice haſt pleas'd to ſhew thy ſelf
To reprehend my falſhood; now vouchſafe
To ſee my low ſubmiſſion. Del. and Druſ. ſhew themſelves.

sp.speaker: Del.
sp.l: What's thy will?
Falſe, and ungrateful (and in that deſerving
All human ſorrows) dar'ſt thou hope from me,
Relief, or Comfort?

sp.speaker: Dio.
sp.l: Penitence can appeaſe
Th' offended Pow'rs; and Sacrifice takes off
Their heavy Angers; thus I render both.
The Maſter of great Rome; and in that Lord
Of half the Sun gives heat, and being to,
Thus ſues for Mercy. Be but as thou wert,
The Bark, and Pilot of my future Fortunes,
And once more ſteer my Actions to the Port
Of glorious Honour; then if I fall off,
Or break my Faith again to this ſweet Virgin,
Join with thoſe Powers who puniſh Perjury,
To make me an example, to deter
Others from being falſe.

sp.speaker: Druſ.
sp.l: Upon my Soul,
You may believe him now: he ne're propos'd
Ought but what's Noble to me; he only try'd
How I could bear unkindneſs. I ſee truth
Triumphant in his ſorrow. Deareſt Aunt,
Both credit him, and help him. Sure you can't,
You can't deny us both, when we thus Plead;
Thus, on our Knees, we both implore your Pardon,
Your Favour, and Aſſiſtance.

sp.speaker: Dio.
sp.l: How happy had I been, had I ne're lookt,
Beyond this abſtract of all Womans goodneſs!

sp.speaker: Del.
sp.l: Riſe both,
I know you are ſincere, and I forgive you:
But had you perſever'd in your Ingratitude,
I had perſu'd you with ſuch dreadful torments,
That Life it ſelf had been a burthen to you.

sp.speaker: Dio.
sp.p: Could you have added to this Affliction?

sp.speaker: Del.
sp.l: Yes, much more: The proud Aurelia
Should have receiv'd the ſame Indignities
She had impos'd on the fair Perſian Princeſs:
Which would have gaul'd her haughty Spirit ſo,
Till Spite, Rage, and Diſpair had made her mad,
And kill her ſelf.

sp.speaker: Dio.
sp.p: And I had been the cauſe of all this woe.

sp.speaker: Del.
sp.l: I'll ſhew you what a Noble Monument
You would have rais'd to the Memory of this Princeſs.

div.stage: She waves her Wand thrice. Soft Muſick is heard. Then the Curtain riſes, and ſhews a ſtately Tomb: Aurelia lying in the midſt of it, on a Bed of State.

sp.speaker: Del.
sp.l: What ſay you now, my Son?
Is my Art to be contemn'd?

sp.speaker: Dio.
sp.l: Ha! 'tis the real Perſon of Aurelia!
The livelineſs of her Complexion;
The brightneſs of thoſe all-commanding Eyes
Aſſure me 'tis no Viſion. 'Tis the true,
The real, living Princeſs.

sp.speaker: Del.
sp.p: You are deceiv'd, it is Illuſion all.

div.stage: Delphia ſtamps, and it vaniſhes: behind it is ſeen a large Cupola, ſupported by Termes on Pedeſtals. The Propheteſs waves her Wand, the Termes leap from their Pedeſtalls, the Building falls, and the Termes and Cupola are turn'd into a Dance of Butterflies.

sp.speaker: Del.
sp.l: Come Son, be not dejected;
I know the cauſes of your diſcontent;
Know you believe your Fame and Honour ſuffers
In their Captivity. Hear Diocleſian;
Deſpiſe me, puniſh me for an Impoſtor,
If Fortune waits not on thy Sword, and Victory,
And glorious Victory attends thy Arms!
If thou redeem'ſt not all thy Friends, and haſt not
Thy mightieſt Enemies at thy diſpoſal.

sp.speaker: Del.
sp.l: Yet remember,
When you are rais'd up to the higheſt point
Of human Happineſs; ſuch as move beyond it,
Muſt of neceſſity deſcend: think on it;
Remember you'r a man, and uſe thoſe Bleſſings
The Gods beſtow, with moderation.

sp.speaker: Dio.
sp.l: I will.
And when I have attain'd this Happineſs,
Even in the height of my exalted Glory;
Something I'll do, ſomething ſo ſingular,
All Monarchs ſhall admire, and but few imitate.

sp.speaker: Dio.
sp.l: Come my Druſilla,
Give me thy Hand, and pray for my ſucceſs. Exeunt

div.stage: Scene a Forreſt.
Enter Niger, Geta, Guard, and Soldiers.

sp.speaker: Nig.
sp.l: How do you like your entrance to the War?
When the whole Body of the Army moves,
Is't not a glorious ſight?

sp.speaker: Get.
sp.l: 'Tis a fine May-game.
But Eating and Drinking is forbidden in't;
I mean with leaſure. We walk on, and feed
Like hungry Boys that haſte to School; or as
We carried Fiſh to the City, dare ſtay no where
For fear our Ware ſhould ſtink.

sp.speaker: 1 Gua.
sp.p: That's the neceſſity of our ſpeedy March.

sp.speaker: Get.
sp.l: Sir, I love my eaſe: I hope a Captain,
(And a Gown'd Captain too, one who has ſate
In Furrs upon a Seat of Judicature,
Repreſenting the Emperor) may be diſpenc'd with.
I tell you, and do not mock me, when I was Poor,
I could indure like others, Cold, and Hunger;
But ſince I grew Rich, let my Finger ake,
Or feel but the leaſt pain in my great Toe,
Unleſs I have a Doctor, my own Doctor too,
That will inſure my Life; I think I am gone.

sp.speaker: Nig.
sp.p: Come, fear not, you ſhall want nothing.

sp.speaker: 1 Gua.
sp.p: We'll make you fight, as you were mad.

sp.speaker: Get.
sp.l: Not too much of fighting, Friend;
It is thy Trade, thou art a private Soldier.
We Officers, by our Places, muſt be fine,
And ſtrut, and make a noiſe, get all we can,
But ſtill be careful to preſerve our Carcaſſes.

sp.speaker: 1 Gua.
sp.l: You are miſtaken; you muſt kill for Exerciſe,
A Dozen or two a Day.

sp.speaker: Get.
sp.l: Thou talk'ſt
As thou wert Louſing thy ſelf. However,
I'll have the fear of Heaven before my Eyes,
And do no hurt, I warrant you.

sp.speaker: Nig.
sp.l: Come, march on then;
And humour him for our mirth ſake.

sp.speaker: 1 Gua.
sp.l: Come Captain; now we are near the Enemy,
You ſhall have ſport I warrant you, and quickly.

sp.speaker: Get.
sp.l: Sport do you call it?
Knocking out one anothers Brains a ſport?
Deliver me!

sp.speaker: Nig.
sp.l: He's one pleaſes the Emperor with his Folly,
And in that a Wiſe man, and a Valiant.

div.stage: A flat Scene of Tents.
